Sorry, this is an old issue, but afaik it is not solved. The issue is not that you cannot change the interpreter from the command line. The issue is that in the JSON config it is not possible to change the interpreter. My use case is starting a node Haraka mail server from PM2. `haraka .` is the way to start, last time I was not able to figure out how to start it using PM2 using a JSON config
Are you sure that you launched pm2 with `-x` (aka `fork_mode`) ?

Yeah I tried. I think we are still talking about a different thing here... I am talking about the JSON app declaration, see https://github.com/Unitech/PM2/blob/development/ADVANCED_README.md#json-app-declaration.

In a JSON app declaration it is not possible to declare a different interpreter than `node`, this issue is about being able to specify a different interpreter in the JSON, to give the JSON syntax feature parity with the CLI syntax.
@timruffles comment above has a nice example which I expected to work

If you want to set an interpreter use the following syntax on a json-declaration:

```
{
    "name": "php-script",
    "exec_interpreter" : "php",
    "exec_mode"  : "fork_mode" //this is important, cluster_mode will only work with node
}
```

Thanks for the advice, but that still doesn't work, and you still [haven't documented it](https://github.com/Unitech/PM2/blob/development/ADVANCED_README.md#deployment-help).

I created an example for you - use the [demo.json from this repo](https://github.com/timruffles/pm2-bug-demo) you'll see that.

## Steps

```
$ git clone git@github.com:timruffles/pm2-bug-demo.git
$ cd pm2-bug-demo
$ bash hello
this works
this works
<Ctrl-C>
$ ruby another
hi there
hi there
<Ctrl-C>
$ npm i
$ cat demo.json
{
  "apps" : [{
    "name"       : "hello",
    "interpreter": "bash",
    "exec_mode"  : "fork_mode"
  }, {
    "name"       : "another",
    "interpreter": "ruby",
    "exec_mode"  : "fork_mode"
  }]
}
$ pm2 start demo.json
$ pm2 l
```

and I see 0 processes running.
